title: Linguistics and Language Theory
description: Specialized vocabulary for linguistic analysis and language philosophy

items.definition: The study of how context contributes to meaning beyond the literal semantic content
items.example: Pragmatics explains why 'Can you pass the salt?' is understood as a request, not a question about ability.

items.definition: Words or phrases whose meaning depends on the context of utterance (person, place, time)
items.example: 'Here,' 'now,' and 'I' are deictic expressions—their reference shifts with each utterance.

items.definition: The smallest meaningful unit in a language
The smallest unit of sound that distinguishes meaning in a language
items.example: The /p/ and /b/ phonemes distinguish 'pat' from 'bat' in English.

items.definition: An utterance that performs an action by being spoken
items.example: 'I hereby pronounce you married' doesn't describe but performs the act of marrying.

items.definition: An implicit assumption that must be true for an utterance to be felicitous
items.example: 'Have you stopped lying?' presupposes that the addressee has been lying.

items.definition: Meaning conveyed beyond what is literally said, through conversational inference
items.example: Saying 'Some students passed' implicates that not all passed, though this isn't literally stated.

items.definition: The hypothesis that language influences or determines thought patterns
items.example: Linguistic relativism suggests that speakers of different languages may perceive the world differently.
